Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying and Predicting the Attenuation of Downstream Fluxes Associated with Beaver Meadows
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predicted warming and drying across much of the U.S. will stress existing water supplies for consumptive activities, as well as ecosystem health and resilience. This is particularly true for the arid and semi-arid regions of the western U.S., including headwater states such as Colorado. Given the predicted increased potential for droughts and floods in the region, the ability to retain and gradually release water from surface and subsurface retention zones within river basins is important. This study will evaluate the potential for beaver meadows which contain numerous dams, ponds, and multi-thread channels, to substantially attenuate downstream fluxes of water, sediment, organic matter, and nitrate relative to river segments without beaver activity. Results of this work will be important for restoring river function, attenuating flood pulses and augmenting low flow periods, as well as for mitigating potential effects of climate change.

In this study investigators will (1) quantify the magnitude of downstream-flux attenuation as a function of size of the beaver meadow relative to the contributing drainage area and activity/spatial heterogeneity of the meadow, (2) evaluate how meadow position within a catchment affects downstream attenuation, (3) assess the extent and magnitude of landscape alteration in the region, and (4) estimate the potential influence of landscape alteration on hydrologic dynamics across larger spatial extents. Quantitative interdisciplinary methods from both hydrology and geomorphology will be leveraged to quantify relationships between catchment morphology, storage, and flux and to scale these dynamics to larger spatial extents. The research will develop new insights into the buffering capacities offered by retention zones in the form of beaver meadows and develop new conceptualizations and numerical models on the manner in which reach-scale behavior influences catchment-scale process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Across North America many river-floodplain systems have experienced considerable alteration as a consequence of human development, land management, and land use practices. Of particular note and consequence is the widespread loss of beaver in many North American river ecosystems. When present, beaver have the potential to create complex fluvial landscapes and help establish hydrologic connections between rivers and floodplains. These hydrologic connections, or the bi-directional movement of water between rivers and floodplains, provide many beneficial ecosystem services including flood attenuation and water quality improvement.

 

Our research has demonstrated that landscape complexity and soil moisture differ significantly between river-floodplain systems with and without beaver activity. Beaver activity facilitates high landscape complexity and bi-directional movement of water between the river and floodplain. The bi-directional movement of water increases hydrologic residence time and attenuates high flows. The increase in residence time that occurs in connected river-floodplain systems can help maintain or improve water quality and enhance floodplain ecosystem productivity. Our work has also demonstrated that hydrologic connectivity between the river and floodplain can influence the downstream transport of dissolved organic carbon and dissolved inorganic nitrogen, which are important from both ecosystem and water quality perspectives. We have also found that landscape complexity and river-floodplain hydrologic connectivity impart stability in downstream water quality while simultaneously generating high diversity of physical and chemical conditions within the floodplains. We believe that this is the result of the landscape complexity induced by beaver activity in connected river-floodplain systems. Specifically, complex systems have high heterogeneity in hydrologic flowpaths that maintain river network water quality while the diversity of conditions enhance floodplain ecosystems services. In addition to helping to maintain water quality, hydrologic connectivity between the river and floodplain is also important to riparian vegetation. Our research has demonstrated that riparian vegetation in connected river-floodplain systems is less sensitive to interannual climate variability than riparian vegetation in disconnected river-floodplain systems. The greater productivity of riparian vegetation in beaver-engineered rivers, along with the wet soils that limit decomposition of organic material, creates the potential for high concentrations of soil organic carbon. Our research has demonstrated that floodplains modified by beaver activities can serve as important sinks for carbon and help to prevent increases in carbon emissions to the atmosphere. Combined, our results demonstrate that the landscape complexity and hydrologic connectivity created by beaver activity impart resilience in terms of hydrology, water quality, and riparian vegetation in river-floodplain systems.  

 

Through this project we have developed improved conceptual and quantitative understanding of river-floodplain connectivity that will help enhance watershed and river corridor management aimed at promoting watershed resilience and floodplain ecosystem services. Results from this research are being used to help guide river-floodplain restoration efforts and beaver reintroduction in headwater systems of the Colorado Rockies. We have worked with natural resources managers and river restoration practitioners to increase awareness of the ways in which beaver ecosystem engineering enhances desirable qualities of rivers and floodplains. We further have developed both field and remotely sensed approaches to quantify river-floodplain connectivity at local and regional scales that can be used by scientists and managers to assess current conditions and measure impacts of future restoration efforts. Given the importance of headwater regions of North America that provide water resources to millions of downstream users, maintaining or restoring ecosystem function in these settings has broad importance. Continued efforts to enhance understanding and management of these critical ecosystems will help ensure the water resources and ecosystem services that river-floodplain systems provide and promote resilience to continuing environmental change.  

 

During our research, several undergraduate and graduate students were trained in scientific research and in presenting their work to the scientific community and to the public. Insights from the research have also been highlighted in multiple media outlets including NPR and Colorado Water.
